docs.text: Vanquish Score: 8.5/10 Playtime: 5.5 hours Platform: PC Storefront: Steam Vanquish is a 3rd person action shooter where you play as Sam, a special forces soldier in a super suit trying to stop the Russians from using an orbital microwave laser from wiping out another American city. This game was released in 2010 for PS3 originally and you can easily tell it has that classic old action style to it. Each mission has a time tracker at the end with bonus points for a fast clear, among other stats it uses. It also has no store, no skins, no items, no inventory or any other complimentary system. You get 3 guns and 2 grenades at all times, at a “heat” meter that limits your dashing speed boost, slo-mo near death time, and the laser gun weapon. You also have a really bad melee attack that instantly overheats you. That's the extent of the mechanics. There are 13 guns in total, all of which are actually pretty fun to use and different. When you pick up a weapon while you have max ammo with it already it upgrades to a slightly better version up to a maximum. There is basically no downtime in this game. You are always in some sort of action packed firefight zooming across with your boosts and trying to not die and that aspect is really fun. The enemies in the game are actually pretty varied. Beyond the small mob robots you have various deadlier super bots, enemy super suits, weird experiments, tanks, and giant death robots. The level design is surprisingly good for a game of this era. Lots of verticality and not too many reused areas despite being fairly linear and in an orbital colony that from above all looks the same. The story however is pretty lackluster and falls apart pretty quickly if you look at it too closely (like spending an entire arc saving some colonists because they could have intel on enemy positions but that info never comes up again and even if it did it makes no sense that hiding refugees would have anything useful). It definitely feels like Michael Bay could have come up with it. I will say the ending isn’t awful though. There are plenty of neat cutscenes throughout though and those are alright. Overall, I rate Vanquish 8.5 /10. It's a fun action packed high octane shooter that never lets go of the pedal and lets you use a variety of cool weapons to lay waste to a horde of robots and giant mechs. The design is pretty good and the mechanics are simple and straightforward. However the story is forgettable and the game doesn't give you any new tools beyond the first hour to change things up but that's forgivable with its short playtime. The Good ++++ Fun guns and fights +++ Mobility ++ Cool enemies ++ Varied levels + No systems bloat The Bad - Some long cutscenes -- Forgettable story

docs.text: Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora Score: 8/10 Playtime: 90 hours Platform: PC Storefront: Ubisoft Connect Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora is a first person action adventure game set on Pandora, the world from the Avatar movies. You play as one of the few remaining Na'Vi from a clan that was wiped by the RDA when you were children. They had captured the last few children to experiment upon but after a raid several years later you manage to escape. Your goal is (you guessed it) to unite the clans of the area and push the RDA out of the region. You fight across 3 distinct regions uniting 3 clans and defeating many RDA outposts and factories, completing world activiting, helping friends, and collecting a wide array of fauna and flora materials. Final Opinion Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora is a game I struggle to properly review. On one hand, I played this game a lot and never found it to be boring or a chore to do so. On the other hand, the game has a plethora of issues that I found really held it back from being great. I landed on a score of 8 because I had enough fun with it to do multiple DLCs and complete most of the world map. I also thought the story was serviceable and the biomes were a treat to explore. I could not gloss over all the issues this game had with all of it's supporting systems however. It felt like I had to fight against all the extra game systems (inventory, UI, gear, etc) to keep enjoing my moment to moment gameplay. I would only recommend this game to people who like the Ubisoft open world formula (such as Far Cry) and already love the world of Pandora (like me). Otherwise, the game systems will wear you down pretty quickly. The Good ++++ The world is obviously gorgeous as hell. Pandora is visually a really interesting world and I think Ubisoft did a great job at translating that in game. Environments has always been one of their strong suits. The photoluminescence at night, the multiple dozen unique biomes across the regions, the massive unique landscapes, were all cool to see especially from the ground. I also include here the huge diversity in plant and animal life. +++ The Na'vi felt authentic and true to the movies. The Na'vi had nice homes and outfits and behaved pretty much how I would expect them too. It was a good immersive experience combined with the environments. +++ Voice acting was good. I'm a sucker for fully voice acted games, always much preferred over the JRPG style of reading over half the stuff. I think they did a good job with the voice acting here. +++ Getting an ikran is dope. Doing a quest to get your own Ikran to fly around was one of my main hopes for this game and I was so happy it was included. Flying around was great. docs.text: Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora is a first person action adventure game set on Pandora, the world from the Avatar movies. You play as one of the few remaining Na'Vi from a clan that was wiped by the RDA when you were children. They had captured the last few children to experiment upon but after a raid several years later you manage to escape. Your goal is (you guessed it) to unite the clans of the area and push the RDA out of the region. You fight across 3 distinct regions uniting 3 clans and defeating many RDA outposts and factories, completing world activiting, helping friends, and collecting a wide array of fauna and flora materials.

Otherwise, the game systems will wear you down pretty quickly.

docs.text: Balatro Score: 8.5/10 Playtime: 60 hours Platform: PC Storefront: Steam Balatro is a pretty unique rogue-lite card game that uses the typical 52-card deck and classic poker hands as the basis for its gameplay. You goal is to play high scoring poker hands to beat the minimum score of each blind (round) and to play around negative modifiers of the boss blind round. As you move up the rounds you get to buy jokers which help in all aspects of play from economy to score multiplying. You can also purchase cards and upgrade the base score of your poker hands in the shops between rounds. There is no other major goal beyond unlocking every joker (achievements) and decks. Final Opinion My final opinion of Balatro is that its absolutely amazing at grabbing you attention and pulling you into its fun and crazy deckbuilding, but it realy falls flat at keeping things interesting in the long term. The best parts are where you are continuously discovering new builds, new jokers, and new playstyles with different decks. It slowly starts to unravel though as you realise a lot of the given options are simply bad and never worth taking and you start going for the same builds more often to help secure the win. I wish there was more pre-run customization or upgrades and more goals beyond beating round 8 for every single run. The slow build up of powers made the first half of every run just feel way too similar. All that being said, the core gameplay is still really fun and I'm glad I played it. I recommend playing it, but don't expect to find some massively replayable game. The Good ++++ The sound design is legit fire. The little sound effects when cards get scored give pure dopamine hits especially when the score multiplier goes high. Very well done. ++++ Great core gameplay design. What can I say, rogue-lite deckbuilding poker game is just fun. Theres a great gameplay loop here with scoring hands and upgrading the deck. +++ Nice art and retro style. A lot of art was made for all the jokers and card styles that are well done. I enjoyed the retro style of the game a lot. +++ Great deckbuilding options. I liked that every card could have a type (foil, holo, poly, negative, etc) as well and other offects stacked on like stickers. I also enjoyed the wide variety of jokers, and the concept of Tarot / Spectral cards. There were lots of angles to upgrade your run. The Bad -- Early game of each run were too similar. Especially at higher difficulties, it could take up to half the run to start having an interesting deck. Combined with only 1 pre-run customizable option (your deck choice) it got pretty stale. Same scaling upgrades would help makes those higher rounds become more feasable objectives. -- A lack of interesting objectives. Sure making points go up was fun for a while, but I wish there had been something else to change up the gameplay. The boss blind debuffs weren't enough. Nothing to unlock besides 9 decks also means once you have them all theres just nothing to play for in the end.

docs.text: Dredge Score: 8/10 Playtime: 15 hours Platform: PC Storefront: Epic Games Dredge is a little fishing adventure game where you control a small fishing boat in strange lands. You drive around fishing a variety of marine life for money, upgrades, quests and achievements. The story revolves around collecting 4 mysterious artifacts that were lost at the bottom of the sea for some stranger. You have to be weary of your sanity at night as the darkness makes it drop and dangerous creatures come out. Final Opinion In the end I think Dredge is a fine game. I enjoyed collecting all the fish as if I was filling out a Pokedex and pimping out my boat. The horror elements were fun and kept the gameplay from being too one-note. The art style and visual design were very unique and it gave the game an interesting appeal. I just wish all the islands had a more distinct gameplay feel to them. Couldn't help but feel like I had mapped out the entire game after finishing the first island since they all had a similar structure and the game was made so you could do them in any order. I did end up with the impression I was just going through the motions near the end which is a shame. I think the DLC does help adress this but I didn't play them. The Good ++++ Distinct visual style. The drawn comic style of the characters and general feel of the world were very cool. I always appreciate games doing unique visual approaches. ++++ The fish Pokedex is fun. I'm a sucker for collecting things. The journal presented all the found fish in a fun and easy to sort way that make the collecting enjoyable. +++ The world biomes were great. One of the highlights was always reaching a new island to see its style, unique fish, and particular gimmick. They made them all very interesting. ++ Sanity was a good trade-off. It never stopped you from doing anything but it gave interesting decision making regarding night time fishing and using your eldritch abilities. The Bad - Gameplay nitpicks. Too many non-connecting menus in towns. Just let me do all the repairing, purchasing, and selling from one place instead of going back and forth between 3 shops. I also found most sidequests to be particularly useless as book rewards were barely worth it. - Time goes by too fast. Night arrives too fast (forcing retreat to some extend). This made fishing in remote locations extremely tedious due to constant back and forth between dock and fishing spot. -- Each island had the same flow. One of my biggest issues. Each island revolved around 1 specific quest that would open up a particular fishing spot that would give the main quest McGuffin. Nothing else really mattered in the game. Only reason it took longer was constant fishing to upgrade the boat.

docs.text: Ghostrunner II Score: 8.5/10 Playtime: 13 hours Platform: PC Storefront: Epic Games Ghostunner II is a cyberpunk themed first person action slasher / platformer that is a direct sequel to the first game. You still play as Jack, a ghostunner, as you fight an AI cult trying to fill in the power vacuum. You still die instantly if you take any damage so you have to use your abilities wisely in every encounter to defeat all the enemies. There is still a heavy emphasis on platforming with wall runs, dashes, grappling hooks and more. You still have your trusty Katana to one-hit kill most enemies as well. docs.text: Helldivers 2 Score: 8.5/10 Playtime: 13 hours Platform: PC Storefront: Steam Helldivers 2 is a third person cooperative action shooter where you play as soldiers on the front line pushing back against an endless invading for or robots, zergs, and strange alien foes. There is a small overarching plot about saving humanity and specific invasions but most of the game focuses on the missions you dive into which are 20-40 minute long sessions which you can do solo or up to 4 players. You complete objectives around the map and extract before losing all your lives. You collect ressources on those missions to upgrade your ship and your stratagems, which are special or limited weapons / aerial attacks that you can use in missions. Final Opinion As of writing this, Helldivers 2 is still in a weird limbo for me. I feel like I haven't really played enough to appreciate all the game has to offer, but I also kind of stopped playing for now. By all accounts it has everything in it that hits the fun parts of my brain like giant mechas / creatures, huge guns and explosives, giant lasers, epic fights. I feel like my frustration came from the solo experience being too difficult / long, and the muliplayer experience to be a bit too disjointed. I may have put the game down for now but I do hope to revisit it someday. The Good ++++ Badass enemies. The enemies in this game are deadly, they are varied, they have very cool huge units that are awesome to fight and to take down. ++++ Insane arsenal. One of the most unqiue arsenals I've had the pleasure of using in most of my gaming history. Orbital strikes, lasers from space, rocket turrets on call, guided launchers, carpet bombs.. the list goes on. These are awesome. ++ Cool customization. Lots of good free options to modify the look of our helldiver. Plus all the ordonance choices and weapon loadouts. ++ Sound design. Using the ordonance and killing enemies all have very satisfying sounds. The Bad -- Too easy to get lost in maps. I get it, actual warzones don't exactly have lots of landmarks, but the endless mars-like landscape got me confused so many times. Maybe the map just wasn't intuitive enough for me yet due to little play time but I was getting lost more often than I'd like. -- Solo play was too hard. I know, theres 10 levels of difficulty so this really shouldn't be an issue. I wanted do to higher difficulty stuff though, and alone it could be really challenging to break through some areas or get around without dying. The issue was also that finishing objetives solo was much slower for already long sessions. -- Multiplayer was disjointed. My issue here is that non of the objectives actually felt coolaborative. Everyone kinda loaded in and just f'ed off and did their own thing until all obejctives were done and everyone rejoined for extraction. This highlighted again my solo issues since I felt solo even with 3 other squadmates. Even with friends it was tempting to just go do your own thing. Lastly, and this is a personal issue, in multiplayer I felt I couldn't use my fun tools cause everyone who knew more what they were doing already went ahead and use the carpet bomb, nuke, laser on the threat or outpost that needed it. Leaving me feeling like my only options were sub-par uses just to feel like I used it, or to seperate myself to do the fun things on my own. I'm not sure how to beter explain the feeling.

docs.text: Neva Score: 9.5/10 Playtime: 6 hours Platform: PC Storefront: Steam Neva is a 2D action platformer where you explore a dying world with your lovely little wolf companion (Neva) throughout four seasons. In classic platformer fashion you jump, dash and strike through the world solving simple enough puzzles to progress. Each season seas your pet wolf grow and change, gaining new abilities to switch up the gamplay. Connecting it all together is an underlying story of loss, love, and friendship. Final Opinion This was simply a stunning game. The visuals were constantly blowing me away which made it exciting to keep discovering every new zone. I thought the combat flowed really well despite its simplicity (enemy variance helped). I particularly loved the dream sequence and winter season, they had the most striking visuals and better puzzles (mouth teleporters and mirroring). Would highly recommend to anyone for a great little experience in under 5h if they enjoy 2D platforming in the slighest. The Good ++++ The art style is outstanding. From the soft watercolor nature blend in the early seasons to hard edges and contrasting colors iin the darker sections, this game never stopped amazing me. It had glorious set pieces and evoked a lot of emotions through its style and presentation alone. ++++ Gameplay never stopped being interesting. It's a short game, but it managed to introduce something new around every corner. Wether that was a new way to move around, to attack, a level gimmick, or anything else, I never got bored of exploring the setting. +++ Simple, but emotional story. There isn't much dialogue in the game beyond calling for Neva, but nonetheless it does an amazing job at making you feel a lot of emotions purely through visuals, music, and setting. ++ All the nice extras. Its short and sweet at 4h. Its easy to get 100% achievements. It runs smooth like butter. The Bad - It starts a bit slow. My only gripe is that the first 30ish minutes felt a bit slower as it's the usual introduction of all basic game mechanics and Neva has no powers yet. It was also my least favorite season, visually (while still gorgeous mind you).
